boxed-text.p: Reviewing Editor: Lorna Role, Stony Brook

Decisions are customarily a result of the Reviewing Editor and the peer reviewers coming together and discussing their recommendations until a consensus is reached. When revisions are invited, a fact-based synthesis statement explaining their decision and outlining what is needed to prepare a revision will be listed below. The following reviewer(s) agreed to reveal their identity: Ralph DiLeone, Young Hwan Jo.

sec.p: The authors report their findings on the molecular properties of MCH and Hcrt/Ox neurons of the LHA obtained from gene mRNA expression profiling. The data provide insight into the extent of the heterogeneity of these neurons, and contribute to the complex literature on âmixed transmitterâ phenotype of these neurons.

The delineation of the problem, experimental execution, and analysis are carefully completed and for the most part are very clearly presented. The manuscript is beautifully written and the documentation are clear.

However, after the reviewers and I had assessed the manuscript independently, we conferred and identified a few limitations of the current study. We have formulated specific questions about power sufficiency, the mouse lines that are being used for the isolation and analysis and confirmatory immunohistochemistry needed.
These are outlined in more detail below under major issues.
Note that we have specified how each issue must be addressed to render the manuscript apropos for eNeuro.
1. Is the Statistical Power sufficient with such a limited number of source animals?.

The qPCR work starts with mRNA obtained from five male Hcrt/Ox-marked and three male MCH-marked mice for the analysis presented here. For genomic analysis, this is problematic, as variation in a single animal could easily skew the data presented. There is significant concern on the part of both reviewers that with such a low number of source animals, the data may not be representative as it is subject to other effects not addressed here (e.g. litter effects). Using cells as the N for analysis obscures this potential problem and there is no clear attempt to address this.
There are several potential ways to address this issue.

The first is to process cells from more source animals (the reviewers felt that 7 animals/per line, if all male, would be optimal (=14 source animals; 7 per line which means adding 2 mice to the HCrt/Ox group and 4 mice to the MCH mice).
Ideally, since the study should compare males and females, the addition of more source animals in each sex would be ideal (e.g. 7 animals/ line /sex = 28 animals).
The authors should also provide an analysis of the variance of the data obtained from the current number of source animals, comparing the determinations by within animal and between animal groupings.
The actual number of source animals needed per line could then be addressed in a more thorough power analysis.

We do understand that if the authors have not collected cells from more animals that getting the n to sufficient power would likely extend the needed time beyond the 2 month limit. In this case, the authors should contact e Neuro and so that the return date/ status can be altered appropriately.
2. Verification of at least some of the identified PCR targets is needed.

Both reviewers felt that there is a need to validate at least some of the identified markers by immunostaining. In fact, MCH neurons appear to contain nesfatin 1, CART, galanin, proenkephalin, and orphanin FQ transcripts and orexin neurons express transcripts for prodynorphin, nesfatin 1, proenkephalin, etc. Expression of those transcripts does not mean that they indeed express those neuropeptides. Interestingly, all orexin neurons contain prodynorphin transcript.

At a minimum, the reviewers ask that confirmatory immunohistochemistry is done to address this question; i.e. immunostaining for (at least) two of the identified targets is essential ( e.g. immunohistochemistry for both orexin and dynorphin; are there no orexin only neurons?).
3. There are inherent limitations in using transgenic Cre driver lines.

As acknowledged and confirmed by the authors, the original Hcrt/Ox GFP line (Sakurai et al., 1999) only labels a subset of Hcrt/Ox neurons. As a goal of the present study is to understand the heterogeneity of Hcrt/Ox neurons, using a line in which only a subset of the neurons are labeled (reported as ~15% of Hcrt/Ox neurons in other studies using this line), is, at best, problematic as the authors do not understand what subset of Hcrt/Ox neurons are labeling. The MCH labeled line has the opposite problem- neurons that are labeled that clearly do not express MCH.

While the authors note these issue, this suboptimal âinputâ nonetheless limits the breadth and impact of the analysis. Correlations with previous studies were completed on subset (41) of âknown discriminatoryâ genes, but with moderate results in this selective context (0.71 r value with p value unclear). At an absolute minimum these clear limitations of the study must be explicitly delineated in the Discussion.

While overall, the Discussion is impressive and scholarly and reflects the overall effort with the preparation of this manuscript, there is a notable absence of consideration of the limitations of the work.
Minor concern;
1. A recent study (Jeong et al., 2016) shows that ARC POMC neurons express vesicular GABA transporter (Slc32a1), so the authors need to correct the sentence (line 750-751) in the discussion.
